title.narrative: Pakistan (le): Aide ciblée aux pays
Pakistan: Targeted country assistance

description.narrative:
Plans d’assistance technique ciblée aux pays L’assistance technique ciblée aux pays (TCA) est octroyée sous forme de ressources destinées aux partenaires présents dans les pays. La TCA est un élément du cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires (PEF) de Gavi. Le plan de TCA d’un pays est établie selon les besoins exprimés du dit pays lors de l’évaluation conjointe. Un plan comprend une liste d’activités, d’étapes clés, et un budget pour une année dite. L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Targeted country assistance (TCA) are resources provided to in-country partners under Gavi’s partners’ engagement framework (PEF). A country’s TCA plan is based on needs expressed by the country during the joint appraisal discussions. It includes sets of activities, milestones and budget for a given year.Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Supply chain

(1) Developed plans and framework for year 3 Operational Deployment Plan (ODP) for Cold Chain Equipment ( CCE)
(2) Completed EVM assessment report and Costed Improvement Plan (cIP).

target.value:
"Develop an immunization supply chain, Management Information System for vaccine and cold chain, conduct cold chain assessments and bottleneck analysis, develop training module, contribute to cold chain assessment for new vaccine introduction and mass immunization campaign. Contribute EVM and improvement plans, develop EPI supply chain road map
The staff member is also the focal point for COVID 19 vaccine roll out and monitoring appropriate planning and implementation, through monitoring cold chain and C4D specialists at subnational level
Staff member will spend all required time to respond to FEPI and PEPI specific requests, support EPI program management (funding and results) in areas allocated to UNICEF and attend meetings as they are conveyed at national and subnational level (following UNICEF rules and regulations). The relocation of the staff to Gov structure will have to be discussed between UNICEF management and MoH"

comment.narrative: A cold chain assessment was conducted in 2014 which was used as a baseline for cold chain infrastructure development and guided the cold chain optimization platform (CCEOP) application to GAVI in 2016. UNICEF supported the procurement and deployment of 15418 equipment through a three year CCEOP support received from GAVI (11,604 installed in the first two years of CCEOP, 3550 installed in year three of CCEOP). Temperature monitoring devices (RTMDs) are installed in all ILRs to be integrated with the vLMIS for real-time reporting, 600 of the RTMDs will be piloted in health facilities of six districts of Punjab and Sindh, and the lesson learned will guide the scaled up to other locations 11,000 CCE across the country. UNICEF provided support in the construction of 16 warehouses for expanded programme on immunization (EPI), Installation of 33 cold rooms and centralized TMDs in 37 cold rooms as well as generators in 12 warehouses across Pakistan, An effective vaccine management assessment (EVMA) have been completed identifying challenges to be addressed at all levels and accordingly, a system design is underway, aimed at making the distribution network more efficient.

title.narrative:
(1) Integrated 600 CCE with RTMDs.
(2) Documented cold chain equioment optamization plan (CCEOP) implementation and progress on establishment of CCE maintenance infrastructure

title.narrative: UNICEF : Service Delivery

"1. Provinces are efficiently guided and coordinated for urban immunization action plans, and implementation. 2. Documented progress of the implementation of action plans in targetted districts and mega cities. 3. Support provided to the development of Gavi full portfolio/HSS-III planning."

target.value: Provide technical assistance for HSS through immunization system strengthening, and PHC for UHC ; determine the focus, strategies and monitor the implementation, to increase vaccine uptake in urban poor populations with the highest level of inequities.

comment.narrative: As part of the urban action plan, 6 urban consultant were recruited (1 in each province) to the support the implementation of urban specific immunity boosting activities (birth dose, intensified monitoring, supporting campaigns in the megacities,). An urban action plan was developed, with an equity lens in Punjab and Balochistan, while Sindh action plan is pending secretary health approval, and remains KP. The pandemic slowed down the implementation, although most of the strategies included in the EPI recovery plan (intra COVID pandemic) and EPI/PEI synergy activities and ISD are also targeting the 41 SHRUCS in addition to the HSS2 districts (detection of zero dose and defaulters thanks to the integrate referral slip, 24/7 birth dose initiative in Quetta, Peshawar and and Karachi megacities. The training of 3000 vaccinators was interrupted for the MR campaign after 103 trainers were trained and will roll out the activity immediately after the campaign. 30 vehicles have been procured to support mobile vaccination teams /ISD teams in urban poor settings, and are being used for announcement in megacities. Governance strengthening to insure supportive supervision, accountability on the results, and increased investment EPI HR and structures remains the challenge. The highest COVID 19 positivity rates were observed in the megacities and provided an opportunity to identify high risk population for EPI. Minor delays due to the COVID pandemic lockdowns and MR campaign among other competing priorities.

title.narrative: Timely planning and implementation of Immunization strategies to reach missed children, Documented progress on implementation of EPI action plans to reach children with vaccines in targetted districts.

target.value:
"Advocacy, planning and implementation of agreed strategies (Equity led implementation in urban poor and remote rural, ISD (DCP3 package) in SHRUCs). Monitor and measure program implementation, rational use of funding, timely reporting. The staff member is also the focal point for COVID 19 vaccine roll out and monitoring appropriate planning and implementation, through monitoring cold chain and C4D specialists at subnational level
Staff member will spend all required time to respond to FEPI and PEPI specific requests, support EPI program management (funding and results) in areas allocated to UNICEF and attend meetings as they are conveyed at national and subnational level (following UNICEF rules and regulations). The relocation of the staff to Gov structure will have to be discussed between UNICEF management and MoH"

comment.narrative: Same strategies as in Balochistan: after COVID 19 pandemic, mitigation strategies' implemented to limit impact on the regular program (part of EPI recovery plan,) UNICEF has launched the birth dose initiative in 12 sites of Quetta megacity (only 1 site up to February 2020). As a result the coverage for BCG, OPV0 and Hepatitis B at birth rose to 97% (19% previously), thanks to a gender and equity sensitive approach (vaccination desk in the labor rooms, vaccine administered by female vaccinators available 27/7 to give the same opportunity for the birth dose to all babies, regardless of the time of birth), leveraging public private partnership (sites in both public and private facilities). Progress is being made through the digitization of the data system, to follow up each baby after the birth dose, until completion of the schedule. As part of the EPI/PEI synergy opportunities for strengthening the immunity in low coverage areas of which Quetta, through: - joint Planning and supportive supervision of RI, coverage by EPI of zero dose children identified during polio campaigns and AFP surveillance, as well as subsequent follow up for coverage in 672, 568 children in 2021. Quetta benefited as a priority polio district. - An integrated referral slip was developed (EPI, nutrition, ANC/PNC), to detect eligible children during house to house activities conducted by FLW, to link them to the health facility. - Co administration of OPV in EPI campaigns (TCV, MR), - Evening and weekend shifts are planned in the slums (population unavailable in regular opening hours of the health facility) - Health camps organized, offering EPI, nutrition, Wash, curative care, ANC and PNC services, in polio tier 1 districts to reduce the resistance to polio due to many campaigns at close interval. Impact on zero dose and defaulters for routine immunization, was confirmed by the third party vaccination coverage survey (Q1 2021), showing 37.5% FIC compared 28.8% per PDHS 2018.

title.narrative: CDC Foundation

Development of Communications and Surveillance materials, including crisis and risk communication plans. Development of Vaccine Related Event response plan. Training of Federal and Provincial level staff on the VRE plan.

target.value: Adequate and timely response to vaccine related events (VREs) is critical to restoring public trust in vaccines and mitigating long-term impact on the immunization system. Pakistan is particularly vulnerable to VREs due to its weak routine immunization infrastructure. We aim to support Pakistan in the development of a high quality vaccine related event plan, consisting of 4 phases. 1 ? Assessment of AEFI system 2 ? Assessment of communication and surveillance around vaccine related events 3 ? Development of communications and surveillance materials. Identify where more work is needed to be done 4 ? Develop a Vaccine Related Event Response Plan 5 - Training of Federal and Provincial level staff on the VRE plan.

comment.narrative: CDC has helped develop a Federal level VRE response plan for the country. Because of COVID-19 delays and restrictions, we did not have the opportunity to develop provincial level plans, nor train on the plans.

title.narrative: Final report on TCV planning, implementation and lessons learned from Gavi TCV implementation. Final reports of technical assistance for monitoring and evaluation activities.

target.value: Provide technical assistance for Gavi supported TCV introduction approved for Pakistan. Work in collaboration with the MOH and other keep partners for planning and evaluation of the first phase of the introduction in 2019. TCV introduction in Pakistan is especially important to document given the occurence of the extensively drug resistant typhoid outbreak.

comment.narrative: Previously, CDC had been in close touch with AKU and Gavi on the impact evaluation in Pakistan. CDC participated in AKU technical discussion calls on study design and provided feedback. CDC (HQ and country office) have had follow-up discussions with AKU and MOH on NIH-FETP involvement but these discussions have not gone any further. We are looking to reprogram the funds. One potential activity is to improve typhoid surveillance reporting in the weekly SitRep by the MOH. This information from the provinces with typhoid surveillance where FETP are active would help monitor TCV impact.

title.narrative: Initial report on technical assistance for planning and implementation of the campaign.

target.value: Provide technical assistance for the first Gavi-supported Typhoid Gavi supported TCV introduction in Pakistan (approved Gavi application). Work in collaboration with the MOH, WHO and other partners (Aga Khan University) for planning and evaluation of the introduction in 2019 and 2020. CDC will be a key technical partner for AKU for evaluation of the TCV campaign over 3 - 4 years (CDC-HQ activities planned through TCA funds and will responsible for close coordination between the CDC in-country staff and other partners). TCV introduction in Pakistan is especially important to document given the occurence of the extensively drug resistant typhoid outbreak and impact of TCV on XRD outbreak control will be critical.

comment.narrative: Previously, CDC had been in close touch with AKU and Gavi on the impact evaluation in Pakistan. CDC participated in AKU technical discussion calls on study design and provided feedback. CDC (HQ and country office) have had follow-up discussions with AKU and MOH on NIH-FETP involvement but these discussions have not gone any further. We are looking to reprogram the funds. One potential activity is to improve typhoid surveillance reporting in the weekly SitRep by the MOH. This information from the provinces with typhoid surveillance where FETP are active would help monitor TCV impact.

target.value:
"Advocacy, synergistic approaches with other sectors and within health Support immunization program focus on missed children of Balochistan (urban poor in megacities, remote rural populations), as well as ISD/ synergy activities (implementation of DCP3 pakage in 18 SHRUCS). Provide Technical assistance for hard to reach areas due to insecurity and terrain by using experience in other countries that has helped reduce inequalities for marginalized population. More specifically work with the Government, WHO, local communities and organization in planning and delivery of services tailored to specific areas. By combining intergration with Nutrition and other services, provide services that will improve the uptake of RI and reduce zero dose as well as bring health services to communities. Support the establishment of mobile health to hard to reach areas and make sure that remote and hard to reach communities are reached with services. The staff member is also the focal point for COVID 19 vaccine roll out and monitoring appropriate planning and implementation, through monitoring the EPI specialist, the urban consultant, the ISD consultant, cold chain and C4D specialists at subnational level

comment.narrative: Following the COVID 19 pandemic, to mitigate its impact on the regular program, as part of the EPI recovery plan, UNICEF has launched the birth dose initiative in 12 sites of Quetta district (only 1 site up to February 2020), a megacity with high proportion of urban poor populations. As a result the coverage for BCG, OPV0 and Hepatitis B at birth rose to 97% (19% previously), thanks to a gender and equity sensitive approach (vaccination desk in the labor rooms, vaccine administered by female vaccinators available 27/7 to give the same opportunity for the birth dose to all babies, regardless of the time of birth), leveraging public private partnership (sites in both public and private facilities). Progress is being made through the digitization of the data system, to follow up each baby after the birth dose, until completion of the schedule. As part of the EPI/PEI synergy opportunities for strengthening the immunity in low coverage areas of which Quetta, through: - joint Planning and supportive supervision of RI, coverage by EPI of zero dose children identified during polio campaigns and AFP surveillance, as well as subsequent follow up for coverage in 672, 568 children in 2021. Quetta benefited as a priority polio district. - An integrated referral slip was developed (EPI, nutrition, ANC/PNC), to detect eligible children during house to house activities conducted by FLW, to link them to the health facility. - Co administration of OPV in EPI campaigns (TCV, MR), - Evening and weekend shifts are planned in the slums (population unavailable in regular opening hours of the health facility) - Health camps organized, offering EPI, nutrition, Wash, curative care, ANC and PNC services, in polio tier 1 districts to reduce the resistance to polio due to many campaigns at close interval. Impact on zero dose and defaulters for routine immunization, was confirmed by the third party vaccination coverage survey (Q1 2021), showing 37.5% FIC compared 28.8% per PDHS 2018.

title.narrative: World Bank : Health Financing/Sustainability
Bottlenecks to primary health services-related budget/funds flow to sub-national/specific geographic areas identified.

target.value: Gavi funds over the past few years were used to provide technical assistance to the federal and provincial governments of Pakistan to enhance capacity for health accounting (through the immunization accounts which includes off-budget) and expenditure tracking to ensure that immunization funds are managed in a transparent and accountable manner. With TCA 2021, the World Bank will focus on i) improving budget autonomy and expenditure efficiency at the primary health centers for integrated health services, ii) strengthening internal control at the primary health centers, including asset management and iii) Dissemination of WB?s report "Towards sustainable financing of routine immunization in Pakistan: A Financial Analysis", funded with NISP BETF/Gavi TCA funds. Budget execution issues highlighted in the report, especially between federal and provincial levels will also be explored further to provide practical recommendations taken forward through TA to the Government within country engagement.

comment.narrative: Gavi TCA leveraged a larger program of work in Pakistan, including: 1. Review of National Immunization accounts. Based on years of capacity building, the EPI team for the first time has prepared national immunization accounts on its own. The consultant who have been working with them in past provided quality assurance this year. The EPI team will present immunization accounts during upcoming joint appraisal mission. 2. Guidelines for Chief Finance and Account Officer (CFAO) in Ministry of Health. The federal PFM law of 2019 now requires that each ministry should be assigned a CFAO, who will assist the Secretary with budget preparation and will be a liaison between finance and ministry. A CFAO has been assigned in Ministry of Health. With TCA funds, we developed guidelines to assist CFAO in discharge of his responsibilities. These guidelines are discussed with the CFAO and MoF. The guidelines will strengthen internal control of the ministry of Health. 3. Internal Audit guidelines for Health ? We are in discussion with MoF for institutionalizing internal audit in MoH. It also suggests institutional structure for internal audit. 4. Policy note on Strong Public Financial Management System to attain Universal Health Coverage in a decentralized service delivery system?: A draft policy paper drawing lessons from PFM reforms in NISP to guide implementation of essential health service package at districts and primary health care. 5. Internal control assessment at primary health care centers. The assessment includes deep dive in the Basic health unit expenditure and suggest ways to improve expenditure efficiency. 6. Budget expenditure analysis the assessment includes provincial analysis over a period of 3 years of both UHC and its associated budgets and secondly district wise results, with template to ensure sub national monitoring 7. Assessment of National Health Accounts: Assessment and comparison with system of health accounts was carried out

title.narrative: Dissemination of WB?s report "Towards sustainable financing of routine immunization in Pakistan: A Financial Analysis"

target.value: Gavi funds over the past few years were used to provide technical assistance to the federal and provincial governments of Pakistan to enhance capacity for health accounting (through the immunization accounts which includes off-budget) and expenditure tracking to ensure that immunization funds are managed in a transparent and accountable manner. With TCA 2021, the World Bank will focus on i) improving budget autonomy and expenditure efficiency at the primary health centers for integrated health services, ii) strengthening internal control at the primary health centers, including asset management and iii) Dissemination of WB?s report "Towards sustainable financing of routine immunization in Pakistan: A Financial Analysis", funded with NISP BETF/Gavi TCA funds. Budget execution issues highlighted in the report, especially between federal and provincial levels will also be explored further to provide practical recommendations taken forward through TA to the Government within country engagement.

comment.narrative: The Financial sustainability report is disseminated to the government and the partners. A webinar was organized on April 19 to present and discuss results of this work with the EPI Director, BMGF, Gavi and partners.

title.narrative: Roadmap to improve financial sustainability discussed with government

target.value: Gavi funds over the past few years were used to provide technical assistance to the federal and provincial governments of Pakistan to enhance capacity for health accounting (through the immunization accounts which includes off-budget) and expenditure tracking to ensure that immunization funds are managed in a transparent and accountable manner. With TCA 2020, the World Bank will focus on the financial sustainability of immunization financing with GAVI transitioning and strenthening controls and accountability to ensure that funds are used for purpose intended. This work will build upon findings of the WB?s work on analytics assessing the control assessment and financial sustainability and efficiency of immunization financing expected to be completed by March 2020.

comment.narrative: The roadmap for financial sustainability is developed and agreed with the counterparts.

title.narrative: CDC Foundation : Vaccine-Specific Support
Report on disease surveillance and impact evaluation activities. Final report on campaign coverage.

target.value: Provide technical assistance for the first Gavi-supported Typhoid Gavi supported TCV introduction in Pakistan (approved Gavi application). Work in collaboration with the MOH, WHO and other partners (Aga Khan University) for planning and evaluation of the introduction in 2019 and 2020. CDC will be a key technical partner for AKU for evaluation of the TCV campaign over 3 - 4 years (CDC-HQ activities planned through TCA funds and will responsible for close coordination between the CDC in-country staff and other partners). TCV introduction in Pakistan is especially important to document given the occurence of the extensively drug resistant typhoid outbreak and impact of TCV on XRD outbreak control will be critical.

comment.narrative: CDC Foundation was unable to re-program the funds and intends to return the unspent funds to Gavi. CDC is in discussion with WHO CO, EPI, and NIH to identify opportunities to strengthen typhoid surveillance and to conduct a deep dive into factors associated with being unvaccinated among eligible children with confirmed typhoid fever for 2022.

target.value: Provide technical assistance for the first Gavi-supported Typhoid Gavi supported TCV introduction in Pakistan (approved Gavi application). Work in collaboration with the MOH, WHO and other partners (Aga Khan University) for planning and evaluation of the introduction in 2019 and 2020. CDC will be a key technical partner for AKU for evaluation of the TCV campaign over 3 - 4 years (CDC-HQ activities planned through TCA funds and will responsible for close coordination between the CDC in-country staff and other partners). TCV introduction in Pakistan is especially important to document given the occurence of the extensively drug resistant typhoid outbreak and impact of TCV on XRD outbreak control will be critical.

comment.narrative: Previously, CDC had been in close touch with AKU and Gavi on the impact evaluation in Pakistan. CDC participated in AKU technical discussion calls on study design and provided feedback. CDC (HQ and country office) have had follow-up discussions with AKU and MOH on NIH-FETP involvement but these discussions have not gone any further. We are looking to reprogram the funds. One potential activity is to improve typhoid surveillance reporting in the weekly SitRep by the MOH. This information from the provinces with typhoid surveillance where FETP are active would help monitor TCV impact.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Demand Promotion & ACSM
Documentation of demand generation activities for integrated services and new vaccine introductions in Pakistan.

target.value:
"Provide technical support in coordinating Human Centered Design (UCD) approaches to enhance community engagement interventions with PEI program, expanded partners and CSOs network to identify and refer missed/zero dose children for vaccination and create demand for immunization/integrated services in high risk, hard to reach areas and mega cities, including urban slums.
The staff member is also the focal point for COVID 19 vaccine roll out and monitoring appropriate planning and implementation, through monitoring cold chain and C4D specialists at subnational level
Staff member will spend all required time to respond to FEPI and PEPI specific requests, support EPI program management (funding and results) in areas allocated to UNICEF and attend meetings as they are conveyed at national and subnational level (following UNICEF rules and regulations). The relocation of the staff to Gov structure will have to be discussed between UNICEF management and MoH "

comment.narrative: Duplication: Milestone progress already reported above. This milestone needs to be removed as its a duplication.

target.value: Work in close coordination with EPI-PEI program and expanded parteners for integrated services around demand generation in high risk, hard to reach and targetted mega cities including urban slums.

comment.narrative: Tailored ACSM interventions have been designed to address specific demand generation needs of communities in hard to reach, remote rural, urban slums, conflict prone and Polio Tier 1 districts. The interventions will utilize elements like influencer advocacy for change; human-centric community engagement for social and behavior change and risk management; social mobilization; and mass/social media engagement; technology for monitoring and reporting public sentiment; and public-private partnerships. The interventions have been laser focused in target union councils. EPI Rebranding exercise in 49 Centers in SHRUCs of Balochistan, KP and Sindh has been successfully completed. The status sheet for the first 50 centers can be accessed through the following link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Cj9RhpODSMxd6whoHWjLmjQDljTEUTcpuxyYeezRBfE/edit#gid=678146720. 1403 centers will be rebranded during and rebranding work has been started from KP. Contracts with five CSOs for community engagement interventions are in place all provinces except KP including 10 mega cities. Action plans of all 5 CSOs on board have been approved and social profiling and baseline assessment will be completed by third week of June in Sindh, Balochistan, ICT/RWP and GB. New content was developed for digital media and field level community engagement for WIW activities and shared through EPI, PEI, MoH and UNICEF social media platforms and also through the mass media campaign during WIW. Federal EPI has recently approved mass media awareness activities for TV and Radio for quarter 3 and 4 for the MR campaign. Digital media campaigns were conducted with the exclusive hashtags of #MissionTyphoid (TCV Campaign 2021) and #VaccinesForPakistan (WIW 2021) in 2021 with a total reach of 30 million and 19 million respectively. The support also resulted in expanding Federal EPI?s official Facebook page?s reach to 59 million. vaccinators training on IPC, ToTs will begin from end-June 2021.

comment.narrative: Social profiling of target communities to understand the root causes was conducted, and identifies reasons for low coverage: perception of vaccines, experience at facility, views on vaccine preventable diseases. This data will guide the development of district specific communication action plans using human centered design approaches (in Dec 2021, after the MR campaign). A total of 6 CSOs were engaged to strengthen community structures and ownership, establish health committees in selected locations aiming at empowering the communities to self monitor the vaccination status of their children refer children for vaccination (detect and refer), for resilience and sustainability. Digitize the referral system between communities and service providers for better accountability Improve IPC skills of frontline workers to convince/reassure caregivers Provide access to accurate information in local languages through all available comms channels to reduce misinformation and vaccine hesitancy.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Supply Chain & Procurement

(1) Integrated 600 CCE with RTMDs.
(2) Documented cold chain equioment optamization plan (CCEOP) implementation and progress on establishment of CCE maintenance infrastructure

target.value: Support the functionality and strenghtening of the Federal and Provincial immunization supply chain systems at all levels

comment.narrative: The integration of the 600 RTMDs into the vLMIS was delayed due to funding gaps for its procurement through the non-CCEOP from NISP-WB. This is resolved now and working with SD for supply of devices. We hope this activity would commence by 4th quarter of 2021. The country has received its first batch of equipment of the CCEOP and discussion is ongoing between the vendor and the Provincial Project Monitoring Team (PMT) on Operational Deployment Plan (ODP) revision and prioritization. Not all required equipment has been received. Implementation of the CCEOP CCE would likely begin within the next month. Its after this that the planning for establishment of maintenance infrastructure would begin. The major progress update for this activity is that the processes for implementation have started, the National Logistic Working Group (NLWG) have discussed and agreed on the provinces to prioritize installations.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Programme Implementation/Coverage & Equity
Documented progress on implementation of costed action plans to reach children with vaccines in targetted districts.

target.value: Provide technical assistance to the planning, development, implementation and monitoring of integrated immunization/health action plans in all targeted districts including urban settings including Quetta City and polio super highrisk union councils to ensure universal immunization coverage.

comment.narrative: Action plan for Quetta including ACSM Plan, evening shifts, involvement of CSOs and implementation of 24/7 birth dose initiative is in progress. UNICEF continued supporting the roll out of 24/7 vaccination centres in maternity rooms of secondary and tertiary care hospitals from 4 sites in Quetta to 12 sites, both in public and private sector. In Quetta, 40,986 out of 42012 live births (98%) have been vaccinated. ISD and referral is also being implemented in SHRUCs of Quetta block.

target.value: Provide technical assistance to the planning, development, implementation and monitoring of integrated immunization/health action plans in all targeted districts including urban settings including Quetta City and polio super highrisk union councils to ensure universal immunization coverage.

comment.narrative: Action plan for Quetta including ACSM Plan, evening shifts, involvement of CSOs and implementation of 24/7 birth dose initiative is in progress. UNICEF continued supporting the roll out of 24/7 vaccination centres in maternity rooms of secondary and tertiary care hospitals from 4 sites in Quetta to 12 sites, both in public and private sector. In Quetta, 40,986 out of 42012 live births (98%) have been vaccinated. ISD and referral is also being implemented in SHRUCs of Quetta block.

title.narrative: Documented progress on equitable delivery of immunization services at all levels (Provincial,District,Facility and Community level).

target.value: Provide technical assistance to provincial, district, area and facility level in equity focused planning/ microplanning, implementation of plans and monitoring at all levels in repective provinces

comment.narrative: UNICEF Pakistan supported provincial and district health authorities to develop costed action plans for Lahore, Peshawar and Quetta under the leadership of provincial and district EPI. These city-specific action plans were informed by the urban slum profiling and immunization coverage survey results. Moreover, UNICEF Pakistan engaged international staff/consultants and in-country partners to support the government in the development of those plans. The same action plans have been reviewed and are being updated for 2021 in abovementioned targeted mega cities. The implementation of these action plan is delayed due to frequent lockdown due to third wave of covid- 19 pandemic. Additionally, to increase the proportion of Penta 3 coverage to 80 per cent in the profiled slums of three union councils of Lahore, UNICEF contracted a third party to conduct a situation analysis and roll out integrated vaccination services including social mobilization in targeted union councils. Implementation will be followed by an evaluation and documentation of lessons learned. This activity will be completed by July 2021. To increase routine immunization coverage (Penta 3, measles 1) and other health, nutrition, WASH interventions in urban cities, UNICEF Pakistan engaged provincial-level consultants and field monitors to provide technical support for planning and monitor implementation and take real time corrective actions. This support has helped to both build the EPI system and structure for integrated primary healthcare services in urban settings as well as help ensure their sustainability. All four provincial level consultants are onboard in Lahore, Quetta, Peshawar and Karachi to undertake this activity

title.narrative: Integrated health service delivery action plans implemented in identified low performing districts including targetted mega cities to increase routine immunization coverage.

target.value: Provide technical assistance in the planning, development, implementation and monitoring of integrated Immunization/health strategies including EPI/PEI synergy. Strengthen coordination and partenerships with key stakeholders to reach missed and underserved children with immunization and basic PHC services through immunization system strengtheing.

comment.narrative: UNICEF provided support to the national expanded programme on immunization (EPI) to review, update and thereby strengthen the existing EPI policy to enhance equity and coverage through systematic collection of gender disaggregated data, promotion of integrated service delivery, strengthening PPP, increasing the number of sessions for BCG and Measles per week in the high burden UCs and opening daily BCG and measles vials at secondary and tertiary level to reduce missed opportunities. These measures are aiming to contribute to mitigating the Negative impact of COVID 19 pandemic on the coverage. Additionally, UNICEF supported the federal EPI to develop and implement an immunization recovery plan during covid-19 pandemic. The implementation of the recovery plan has helped to maintain and sometimes improve the coverage of essential immunization at all levels. UNICEF further selected CSOs for community engagement in mega cities and HSS2 priority districts. UNICEF also supported inclusion of profiled 4500 slums in microplans of Karachi. Moreover, UNICEF supported prototype for urban slums is being rolled out in other targeted UCs of mega cities through same organization, CHIP, as expanded partner. The implementation targeted interventions in mega cities resulted in15-20 per cent increase in immunization coverage. UNICEF continued supporting the roll out of 24/7 vaccination centres in maternity rooms of secondary and tertiary care hospitals at 12 sites in Quetta,06 sites in Karachi and Hyderabad and 08 sites in KP, in both public and private sector. Through this initiative, about 40,986 of 42,012 (98%) new-born were vaccinated. UNICEF is also providing technical support for trainings of 3,000 newly recruited vaccinators in all provinces and areas and will be completed by Q4 of 2021. UNICEF is also supporting implementation of SHRUCs action plan and Health camps in Peshawar and Karachi to reach to zero dose, due and defaulters for essential immunization program.

target.value: Provide technical assistance in the planning, development, implementation and monitoring of integrated Immunization/health strategies including EPI/PEI synergy. Strengthen coordination and partenerships with key stakeholders to reach missed and underserved children with immunization and basic PHC services through immunization system strengtheing.

comment.narrative: UNICEF provided support to the national expanded programme on immunization (EPI) to review, update and thereby strengthen the existing EPI policy to enhance equity and coverage through systematic collection of gender disaggregated data, promotion of integrated service delivery, strengthening PPP, increasing the number of sessions for BCG and Measles per week in the high burden UCs and opening daily BCG and measles vials at secondary and tertiary level to reduce missed opportunities. These measures are aiming to contribute to mitigating the Negative impact of COVID 19 pandemic on the coverage. Additionally, UNICEF supported the federal EPI to develop and implement an immunization recovery plan during covid-19 pandemic. The implementation of the recovery plan has helped to maintain and sometimes improve the coverage of essential immunization at all levels. UNICEF further selected CSOs for community engagement in mega cities and HSS2 priority districts. UNICEF also supported inclusion of profiled 4500 slums in microplans of Karachi. Moreover, UNICEF supported prototype for urban slums is being rolled out in other targeted UCs of mega cities through same organization, CHIP, as expanded partner. The implementation targeted interventions in mega cities resulted in15-20 per cent increase in immunization coverage. UNICEF continued supporting the roll out of 24/7 vaccination centres in maternity rooms of secondary and tertiary care hospitals at 12 sites in Quetta,06 sites in Karachi and Hyderabad and 08 sites in KP, in both public and private sector. Through this initiative, about 40,986 of 42,012 (98%) new-born were vaccinated. UNICEF is also providing technical support for trainings of 3,000 newly recruited vaccinators in all provinces and areas and will be completed by Q4 of 2021. UNICEF is also supporting implementation of SHRUCs action plan and Health camps in Peshawar and Karachi to reach to zero dose, due and defaulters for essential immunization program.

title.narrative: Documented knowledge products,Case studies, lesson learned, best practices and human interest stories.

target.value: Provide technical assistance to the planning, development, implementation and monitoring of integrated immunization/health strategies in targetted hgh risk distircts including mega cities to ensure universal immunization coverage through immunization system strengthening.

comment.narrative: UNICEF supported provincial and Federal EPI in documentation of lesson learned from TCV campaign in Sindh which has been used to inform implementation of TCV Campaign in Punjab and Islamabad. The report is attached for reference. Two publications have also been developed and are in process of publication.UNICEF also supported EPI Program in documentation of urban slums profiling and immunization coverage survey results in Pakistan. Final report is attached for reference. Three (03) scientific publications have also been developed and being published for knowledge management. UNICEF supported development of ?Strengthening Services Beyond Immunization Approach?, which is being implemented in polio super high-risk union councils in Balochistan, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and Sindh to support polio eradication while enhancing the overall socioeconomic conditions and physical resilience of residents through the provision of basic social services. Immunization services integrated with basic maternal, new-born and child healthcare (MNCH), nutrition, WASH, and birth registration are being implemented to increase the access to and uptake of essential vaccines by target population. During the pilot phase, implemented in 2020/21 across seven super high-risk union councils (SHRUC) in KP, Sindh and Balochistan, a total of 108,187 children received basic primary healthcare services including basic curative services, routine immunization and nutrition services. Additionally, about 250,000 persons (62,500 men, 65,000 women, 61381 boys and 61,119 girls) were reached with WASH services in these SHRUCs.Integrated referral slip initiative has also been launched in seven SHRUCs and is being rolled out in other UCs. UNICEF also supported FEPI in development of Framework for independent monitoring which has been endorsed by all provinces and areas. UNICEF also supported national EPI review meeting in June 2021. The final report with clear action points will be circulated soon.

target.value: Establishing and sustaining the Typhoid surveillance sites in all provinces and areas

comment.narrative: From April 2020 up to April 2021, a total of 14 Typhoid sentinel sites were established, 5 in Punjab, 5 in Sindh, 3 in KP and 1 in Baluchistan. Expansion of number of sites is in process, and additional site in Baluchistan. and one in Islamabad will start functioning from in July 2021. The total of 14,376 suspected typhoid cases were reported, of which 98% (14,146) were tested, 12% (1,679) were lab confirmed typhoid, of which 65% (1,088) were XDR typhoid. (Typhoid Sentinel site report is attached) it?s integrated with private and Academia

comment.narrative: Technical support continued in 4 existing Rota and IBD sites, 2 in Punjab and 2 in Sindh, furthermore, an expansion in 2 more sites took place in Punjab and 2 in KP Increasing the total number of Rota sites to 8.There is a plan to include 1 more site in Baluchistan. Technical and logistic support continues in all new and existent sites.

target.value: Establishing and sustaining the Typhoid surveillance sites in all provinces and areas

comment.narrative: Up to Oct 2021, A total of 16 Typhoid sentinel sites are supported, (5 In Punjab, 5 In Sindh, 3 in KP, 2 in Baluchistan), of which, 1 site was included in the Typhoid surveillance network in July 2021 in Baluchistan. Through sentinel sites surveillance, a total of 31,671 suspected typhoid cases were reported, of which 99% (31,441) were tested. 10% (3,049) were Typhoid lab-confirmed, of which 66% (2,008) were XDR typhoid
